items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign new ceasefire deal after weeks of fighting
items.standfirst: Thailand and Cambodia signed a ceasefire agreement on Saturday after weeks of deadly fighting along their border.
items.content: Thailand and Cambodia signed a ceasefire agreement on Saturday after weeks of deadly fighting along their border.

items.title: Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire starts, first 72 hours seen as critical test
items.standfirst: A ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia has come into effect after weeks of deadly fighting across the border.
items.content: A ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia has come into effect after weeks of deadly fighting across the border.

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign ceasefire agreement after weeks of deadly border clashes
items.standfirst: Thailand and Cambodia on Saturday (December 27) signed a ceasefire agreement after three weeks of fighting that killed at least 47 people and displaced more than a million. FRANCE 24 correspondent, Tommy Walker, tells us more.
items.content: Thailand and Cambodia on Saturday (December 27) signed a ceasefire agreement after three weeks of fighting that killed at least 47 people and displaced more than a million. FRANCE 24 correspondent, Tommy Walker, tells us more.

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree ceasefire after weeks of deadly clashes
items.standfirst: Almost one million people have been displaced since hostilities resumed earlier this month.
items.content: Almost one million people have been displaced since hostilities resumed earlier this month.

items.title: Thailand And Cambodia Agree To Ceasefire In Long-Running Border Dispute, Pledge Peaceful Resolution
items.standfirst: Thailand and Cambodia have agreed to a ceasefire, marking a crucial step towards resolving their long-standing border dispute. According to a joint statement signed by the defense ministers of both Southeast Asian nations, the agreement was reached at the 3rd Special General Border Committee (GBC)…
items.content: Thailand and Cambodia have agreed to a ceasefire, marking a crucial step towards resolving their long-standing border dispute. According to a joint statement signed by the defense ministers of both Southeast Asian nations, the agreement was reached at the 3rd Special General Border Committee (GBC)…

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign new ceasefire agreement to end border fighting
items.standfirst: In addition to ending fighting, the agreement calls for no further military movements by either side and no violations of either side's airspace for military purposes.
items.content: In addition to ending fighting, the agreement calls for no further military movements by either side and no violations of either side's airspace for military purposes.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign ceasefire agreement after weeks of intense fighting
items.standfirst: Thailand and Cambodia have signed a ceasefire agreement to end weeks of armed combat along their border over competing claims to territory.
items.content: Thailand and Cambodia have signed a ceasefire agreement to end weeks of armed combat along their border over competing claims to territory.

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign ceasefire agreement after weeks of deadly border clashes
items.standfirst: Thailand and Cambodia on Saturday signed a ceasefire agreement after three weeks of fighting killed at least 101 people and displaced more than a million. The truce comes after three days of talks, and it applies to "all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures", according to a statement signed by the two countries' defence ministers.
items.content: Thailand and Cambodia on Saturday signed a ceasefire agreement after three weeks of fighting killed at least 101 people and displaced more than a million. The truce comes after three days of talks, and it applies to "all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures", according to a statement signed by the two countries' defence ministers.

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree ‘immediate’ ceasefire after weeks of deadly border clashes
items.standfirst: Two countries pledge in joint statement to halt all forms of attacks and further troop deployments in long-running dispute over contested territoryThailand and Cambodia have agreed to an “immediate” ceasefire, pledging to end weeks of deadly border clashes that have killed more than 100 people and displaced more than half a million on both sides.In a joint statement, the two south-east Asian neighbours said the ceasefire would take effect on Saturday at noon local time and involve “all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures, and military objectives of either side, in all cases and all areas”. Continue reading...
items.content: Two countries pledge in joint statement to halt all forms of attacks and further troop deployments in long-running dispute over contested territoryThailand and Cambodia have agreed to an “immediate” ceasefire, pledging to end weeks of deadly border clashes that have killed more than 100 people and displaced more than half a million on both sides.In a joint statement, the two south-east Asian neighbours said the ceasefire would take effect on Saturday at noon local time and involve “all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures, and military objectives of either side, in all cases and all areas”. Continue reading...

items.title: Thailand, Cambodia Declare Ceasefire, Ending Weeks of Fighting
Thailand and Cambodia agree on ceasefire to end weeks of deadly fighting
items.standfirst: Agreement follows talks aimed at ending weeks of deadly clashes along the Thailand-Cambodia border.
items.content: Agreement follows talks aimed at ending weeks of deadly clashes along the Thailand-Cambodia border.

items.title: Thailand, Cambodia agree on immediate truce
items.standfirst: More to come......
items.content: More to come......

items.title: Thailand bombs Cambodian border area as ceasefire talks continue
items.standfirst: Cambodia accuses Thailand of "indiscriminate attacks", as negotiators meet for a third day to try to end weeks of renewed fighting.
items.content: Cambodia accuses Thailand of "indiscriminate attacks", as negotiators meet for a third day to try to end weeks of renewed fighting.

items.title: Cambodia accuses Thailand of launching strikes during border peace talks
items.standfirst: Thai reports claim Cambodia carried out overnight attacks ahead of officials from both countries meeting for a third day of negotiations on FridayCambodia has accused Thailand of intensifying its bombardment of disputed border areas, even as officials from the two countries attend a multi-day meeting aimed at negotiating an end to deadly clashes.The neighbours’ longstanding border conflict reignited this month, shattering an earlier truce and killing more than 40 people, according to official counts. About a million people have also been displaced. Continue reading...
items.content: Thai reports claim Cambodia carried out overnight attacks ahead of officials from both countries meeting for a third day of negotiations on FridayCambodia has accused Thailand of intensifying its bombardment of disputed border areas, even as officials from the two countries attend a multi-day meeting aimed at negotiating an end to deadly clashes.The neighbours’ longstanding border conflict reignited this month, shattering an earlier truce and killing more than 40 people, according to official counts. About a million people have also been displaced. Continue reading...

clusters.title: U.S. launches strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria, Trump says
clusters.neutral_headline: US launches strikes against Islamic State in Nigeria

items.title: U.S. launches strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria, Trump says
items.standfirst: Strikes against ISIS targets in Nigeria come after President Trump spent weeks accusing the West African country's government of failing to rein in the persecution of Christians.
items.content: Strikes against ISIS targets in Nigeria come after President Trump spent weeks accusing the West African country's government of failing to rein in the persecution of Christians.

items.title: Details emerge about U.S. strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria
items.standfirst: Details are emerging about the Christmas Day military strikes in northern Nigeria. The U.S. launched what President Trump called a "powerful and deadly" strike on ISIS targets in the West African nation. Willie Inman has more.
items.content: Details are emerging about the Christmas Day military strikes in northern Nigeria. The U.S. launched what President Trump called a "powerful and deadly" strike on ISIS targets in the West African nation. Willie Inman has more.

items.title: U.S. launches surprise Christmas Day strikes on ISIS targets in Nigeria
items.standfirst: The president ordered the strikes on militants he accused of “slaughtering” Christians in Nigeria. Meanwhile, President Trump is expected to host Ukrainian President Zelenskyy for peace talks on Sunday. NBC News’ Julie Tsirkin reports.
items.content: The president ordered the strikes on militants he accused of “slaughtering” Christians in Nigeria. Meanwhile, President Trump is expected to host Ukrainian President Zelenskyy for peace talks on Sunday. NBC News’ Julie Tsirkin reports.

items.title: US launches strikes against Islamic State in Nigeria
items.standfirst: President Trump has previously accused the Nigerian government of failing to protect Christians from jihadists.
items.content: President Trump has previously accused the Nigerian government of failing to protect Christians from jihadists.

items.title: Trump's claim US airstrikes in Nigeria hit ISIS targets 'sketchy', presidential adviser tells Sky News
items.standfirst: A special adviser to the Nigerian president has told Sky News details about who the US hit in Christmas Day strikes in the country were "sketchy" - despite Donald Trump's claims.
items.content: A special adviser to the Nigerian president has told Sky News details about who the US hit in Christmas Day strikes in the country were "sketchy" - despite Donald Trump's claims.

items.title: Nigeria signals more strikes likely in 'join' US operations
items.standfirst: Nigeria has indicated that further strikes against jihadist groups may follow a joint operation with the United States that targeted Islamic State group militants in the country’s northwest on Thursday. The foreign minister said Nigeria provided the intelligence for the attack and described cooperation with Washington as ongoing. The US military reported multiple deaths in the Christmas Day bombing, as President Donald Trump reiterated claims that militant groups in Nigeria are targeting “innocent Christians”. For analysis, we hear from Oluwole Ojewale, Coordinator for West and Central Africa at the Institute for Security Studies.
items.content: Nigeria has indicated that further strikes against jihadist groups may follow a joint operation with the United States that targeted Islamic State group militants in the country’s northwest on Thursday. The foreign minister said Nigeria provided the intelligence for the attack and described cooperation with Washington as ongoing. The US military reported multiple deaths in the Christmas Day bombing, as President Donald Trump reiterated claims that militant groups in Nigeria are targeting “innocent Christians”. For analysis, we hear from Oluwole Ojewale, Coordinator for West and Central Africa at the Institute for Security Studies.

items.title: Trump supporters hail US strikes in Nigeria as ‘amazing Christmas present’
items.standfirst: Some even celebrated ‘mass killing’ and the president’s ‘resolve’ in attacking Islamic State targets The US’s Christmas Day strikes against Islamic State targets in Nigeria have been met with praise by Donald Trump supporters who for months had been agitating for the president to respond forcefully to the killings of Christians in the country.“I can’t think of a better way to celebrate Christmas than by avenging the death of Christians through the justified mass killing of Islamic terrorists,” the far-right political activist Laura Loomer posted on X. “You’ve got to love it! Death to all Islamic terrorists! Thank you.” Continue reading...
items.content: Some even celebrated ‘mass killing’ and the president’s ‘resolve’ in attacking Islamic State targets The US’s Christmas Day strikes against Islamic State targets in Nigeria have been met with praise by Donald Trump supporters who for months had been agitating for the president to respond forcefully to the killings of Christians in the country.“I can’t think of a better way to celebrate Christmas than by avenging the death of Christians through the justified mass killing of Islamic terrorists,” the far-right political activist Laura Loomer posted on X. “You’ve got to love it! Death to all Islamic terrorists! Thank you.” Continue reading...

items.standfirst: This blog is now closed. US warns of more Nigeria strikesExplained: Why has Trump ordered strikes in Nigeria?Here are some images of the aftermath of US strikes in Nigeria that have come via the news wires today:Nigerians across Sokoto state told of their shock at Christmas Day strikes by the United States. Continue reading...

items.title: US cooperation with Nigerian government targets Islamic State group
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Thursday that the US had launched "precision hits on terrorist targets in Nigeria by air strikes". The claim came in a Christmas night social media post that offered few details, though US Africa Command later confirmed the strikes were conducted at the request of Nigerian authorities who said multiple Islamic State group militants were killed. Gabriel Nadler reports.
items.content: President Donald Trump said Thursday that the US had launched "precision hits on terrorist targets in Nigeria by air strikes". The claim came in a Christmas night social media post that offered few details, though US Africa Command later confirmed the strikes were conducted at the request of Nigerian authorities who said multiple Islamic State group militants were killed. Gabriel Nadler reports.

items.title: U.S. strikes ISIS in Nigeria. And, holiday shopping was higher than expected
items.standfirst: The U.S. has launched a "deadly strike" against Islamic State fighters in northwest Nigeria, according to Trump. And, holiday spending was higher than expected this year.
items.content: The U.S. has launched a "deadly strike" against Islamic State fighters in northwest Nigeria, according to Trump. And, holiday spending was higher than expected this year.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

items.title: Department of Defense video shows a missile being launched after Nigeria strikes
items.standfirst: The United States carried out strikes against Islamic State militants in northwest Nigeria at the request of Nigeria's government, U.S. President Donald Trump and the U.S. military said.
items.content: The United States carried out strikes against Islamic State militants in northwest Nigeria at the request of Nigeria's government, U.S. President Donald Trump and the U.S. military said.

items.title: U.S. says it struck ISIS in Nigeria after Trump warns of attacks on Christians
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Thursday said he ordered “numerous” strikes on Islamic State terrorists in Nigeria he accused of killing Christians.“The United States launched a powerful and deadly strike against ISIS Terrorist Scum in Northwest Nigeria, who have been targeting and viciously killing, primarily, innocent Christians, at levels not seen for many years, and even Centuries!” Trump said in a post on Truth Social
items.content: President Donald Trump on Thursday said he ordered “numerous” strikes on Islamic State terrorists in Nigeria he accused of killing Christians.“The United States launched a powerful and deadly strike against ISIS Terrorist Scum in Northwest Nigeria, who have been targeting and viciously killing, primarily, innocent Christians, at levels not seen for many years, and even Centuries!” Trump said in a post on Truth Social

clusters.title: Somalia denounces Israeli recognition of Somaliland
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel becomes first country to recognise Somaliland as sovereign state

items.title: Somalia denounces Israeli recognition of Somaliland
items.standfirst: Somalia reacted angrily Friday (December 26) after Israel formally recognised the northern region of Somaliland as an "independent and sovereign state" -- the first country to do so. Somaliland, which declared independence from Somalia in 1991, has for decades pushed for international recognition. US President Donald Trump said he opposed US recognition of Somaliland in an interview with the New York Post.
items.content: Somalia reacted angrily Friday (December 26) after Israel formally recognised the northern region of Somaliland as an "independent and sovereign state" -- the first country to do so. Somaliland, which declared independence from Somalia in 1991, has for decades pushed for international recognition. US President Donald Trump said he opposed US recognition of Somaliland in an interview with the New York Post.

items.title: Trump says US won't recognize Somaliland
items.standfirst: United States President Donald Trump told the New York Post that he will not follow Israel and recognize Somaliland as an independent country."Does anyone know what Somaliland is, really?" Trump told ...
items.content: United States President Donald Trump told the New York Post that he will not follow Israel and recognize Somaliland as an independent country."Does anyone know what Somaliland is, really?" Trump told ...

items.title: Israel becomes first country to recognise Somaliland as sovereign state
items.standfirst: Diplomatic breakthrough criticised by African Union, which said it could have ‘far-reaching implications for peace and stability across the continent’Israel has become the first country to recognise Somaliland as a sovereign state, a breakthrough in its quest for international recognition since it declared independence from Somalia 34 years ago.The Israeli foreign minister, Gideon Sa’ar, announced on Friday that Israel and Somaliland had signed an agreement establishing full diplomatic relations, which would include the opening of embassies and the appointment of ambassadors. Continue reading...
items.content: Diplomatic breakthrough criticised by African Union, which said it could have ‘far-reaching implications for peace and stability across the continent’Israel has become the first country to recognise Somaliland as a sovereign state, a breakthrough in its quest for international recognition since it declared independence from Somalia 34 years ago.The Israeli foreign minister, Gideon Sa’ar, announced on Friday that Israel and Somaliland had signed an agreement establishing full diplomatic relations, which would include the opening of embassies and the appointment of ambassadors. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel recognises Somaliland as independent state, Netanyahu says
items.standfirst: The decision has been condemned by Somalia, Egypt, Turkey and Djibouti, who call it a dangerous precedent.
items.content: The decision has been condemned by Somalia, Egypt, Turkey and Djibouti, who call it a dangerous precedent.

items.title: African Union and Somalia denounce Israel's recognition of Somaliland
items.standfirst: The African Union and Somalia denounced Israel's announcement on Friday that it viewed Somaliland as an "independent and sovereign state". Israel is the first country to recognise Somaliland, which declared independence from Somalia in 1991.
items.content: The African Union and Somalia denounced Israel's announcement on Friday that it viewed Somaliland as an "independent and sovereign state". Israel is the first country to recognise Somaliland, which declared independence from Somalia in 1991.

On Friday, Zelenskyy said he expects to meet Trump "in the near future." Rustem Umerov reported on his latest contacts with the American side. We are…

items.title: Zelenskyy says he will meet Trump on Sunday for Ukraine-Russia talks
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy says he and President Trump have agreed to meet in Florida on Sunday, signaling progress in talks to end the Russia-Ukraine war.
items.content: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy says he and President Trump have agreed to meet in Florida on Sunday, signaling progress in talks to end the Russia-Ukraine war.

items.title: Zelenskyy to travel to US for Trump meeting amid push for Ukraine deal
items.standfirst: Meeting on Sunday will follow flurry of US, Russian and Ukrainian talks, but Putin has shown little sign of softeningVolodymyr Zelenskyy is to travel to the US for a planned meeting with Donald Trump on Sunday, as Washington continues to push for a possible peace deal between Kyiv and Moscow.The Ukrainian president said the visit would take place at a location in Florida – widely expected to be Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort – in what would be the latest development in a diplomatic push that began in November with the circulation of a 28-point US plan shaped with input from Russian officials. Continue reading...
items.content: Meeting on Sunday will follow flurry of US, Russian and Ukrainian talks, but Putin has shown little sign of softeningVolodymyr Zelenskyy is to travel to the US for a planned meeting with Donald Trump on Sunday, as Washington continues to push for a possible peace deal between Kyiv and Moscow.The Ukrainian president said the visit would take place at a location in Florida – widely expected to be Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort – in what would be the latest development in a diplomatic push that began in November with the circulation of a 28-point US plan shaped with input from Russian officials. items.title: Donald Trump to meet Zelensky on Sunday
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Friday that he would meet US President Donald Trump in Florida over the weekend to discuss territory and security guarantees, a day after meeting White House negotiators to discuss ways to end the war in Ukraine. Laurent Berstecher reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Friday that he would meet US President Donald Trump in Florida over the weekend to discuss territory and security guarantees, a day after meeting White House negotiators to discuss ways to end the war in Ukraine. Laurent Berstecher reports.

items.title: Yemeni separatists accuse Saudi Arabia of air strikes in eastern provinces
items.standfirst: Yemen's Southern Transitional Council (STC) separatists on Friday (December 26) accused Saudi Arabia of carrying out air strikes on their positions in the east of the country, a claim Riyadh has not acknowledged.
items.content: Yemen's Southern Transitional Council (STC) separatists on Friday (December 26) accused Saudi Arabia of carrying out air strikes on their positions in the east of the country, a claim Riyadh has not acknowledged.

items.title: Southern Yemeni separatists accuse Saudi Arabia of air strikes in eastern provinces
items.standfirst: Yemen's Southern Transitional Council (STC) separatists on Friday accused Saudi Arabia of carrying out air strikes on their positions in the east of the country, a claim Riyadh has not acknowledged. While vowing they will not be deterred, the STC said it remains open to coordination with the kingdom, underscoring strains within the Saudi-led coalition.
items.content: Yemen's Southern Transitional Council (STC) separatists on Friday accused Saudi Arabia of carrying out air strikes on their positions in the east of the country, a claim Riyadh has not acknowledged. While vowing they will not be deterred, the STC said it remains open to coordination with the kingdom, underscoring strains within the Saudi-led coalition.

items.title: Southern separatists in Yemen report Saudi airstrikes near positions
items.standfirst: Alleged strikes close to UAE-backed forces follow Riyadh’s call for STC to withdraw from newly seized provincesA separatist group in southern Yemen that this month seized two oil-rich provinces has claimed that Saudi Arabia has fired warning airstrikes directed at its forces.Videos issued on Friday by media linked to the United Arab Emirates-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) showed airstrikes that it said were close to its positions in Wadi Nahab, Hadramaut province. Continue reading...

items.title: Russia attacks Kyiv, killing 1 and wounding many ahead of Ukraine-US talks
items.standfirst: Russia attacked Ukraine's capital with missiles and drones early Saturday morning, killing one and wounding over 20 people a day before talks between Ukraine and the U.S., local authorities said.
items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine's capital with missiles and drones early Saturday morning, killing one and wounding over 20 people a day before talks between Ukraine and the U.S., local authorities said.(Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

items.title: Russia attacks Kyiv ahead of Ukraine-US talks

items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine's capital with missiles and drones early Saturday morning (December 27), a day before talks between Ukraine and the US, local authorities said.

items.title: Live: Zelensky says Russia does 'not want to end the war' after massive missile, drone attack
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia’s attack on Ukraine early on Saturday shows that Russia does “not want to end the war”. According to Zelensky, Russia pounded Ukraine with more than 500 drones, wounding at least 20 people and killing one. Follow our liveblog for all the latest updates.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia’s attack on Ukraine early on Saturday shows that Russia does “not want to end the war”. According to Zelensky, Russia pounded Ukraine with more than 500 drones, wounding at least 20 people and killing one. Follow our liveblog for all the latest updates.

items.title: Marmite-scented deodorant tops list of UK’s most unwanted Christmas presents
items.standfirst: Consumer group Which? finds one in five people are unsure what to do with dud gifts after the festive periodMarmite-scented deodorant and already-worn pyjamas have topped the list of the most disappointing Christmas presents, according to research that found one in five Britons have received an unwanted gift in their festive haul.More than 2,000 members of the public were polled by the consumer group Which? in January about the gifts they received last Christmas, with 21% of those surveyed saying they had been given an unwanted or unsuitable present. Continue reading...
items.content: Consumer group Which? finds one in five people are unsure what to do with dud gifts after the festive periodMarmite-scented deodorant and already-worn pyjamas have topped the list of the most disappointing Christmas presents, according to research that found one in five Britons have received an unwanted gift in their festive haul.More than 2,000 members of the public were polled by the consumer group Which? in January about the gifts they received last Christmas, with 21% of those surveyed saying they had been given an unwanted or unsuitable present. clusters.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak jailed for 15 more years in 1MDB graft scandal
clusters.neutral_headline: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak jailed for 15 more years in 1MDB graft scandal

items.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak jailed for 15 more years in 1MDB graft scandal
items.standfirst: New conviction over plunder of state fund substantially increases six-year term in separate case The jailed former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak has been sentenced to an additional 15 years after he was found guilty of abuse of power, in the biggest trial yet in the multibillion-dollar fraud scandal related to the state fund 1MDB.Najib’s conviction substantially increases the six-year prison term he is already serving for a separate case related to the 1MDB graft scandal, one of the world’s biggest financial frauds in which billions were plundered from the now defunct sovereign wealth fund. Continue reading...
items.content: New conviction over plunder of state fund substantially increases six-year term in separate case The jailed former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak has been sentenced to an additional 15 years after he was found guilty of abuse of power, in the biggest trial yet in the multibillion-dollar fraud scandal related to the state fund 1MDB.Najib’s conviction substantially increases the six-year prison term he is already serving for a separate case related to the 1MDB graft scandal, one of the world’s biggest financial frauds in which billions were plundered from the now defunct sovereign wealth fund. Continue reading...

items.title: Ex-Malaysia PM Najib Razak given 15-year jail term over state funds scandal
items.standfirst: Najib was convicted for his role in the billion-dollar scandal involving the country's sovereign wealth fund 1MDB.
items.content: Najib was convicted for his role in the billion-dollar scandal involving the country's sovereign wealth fund 1MDB.
